qas.question: Who first suggested the existence of discrete inheritable units?
If a distinct trait in edible pea plants is mathematically described as a 2n combination, what does n represent?

answers.text: n is the number of differing characteristics in the original peas

qas.question: What is one thing that Gregor Mendel was the first to demonstrate?
What is another thing that Gregor Mendel was the first to demonstrate?

answers.text: the distinction between dominant and recessive traits

qas.question: What did Gregor Mendel explain his results in terms of?

answers.text: discrete inherited units that give rise to observable physical characteristics

context: The existence of discrete inheritable units was first suggested by <a0_0>Gregor Mendel (1822–1884)<a0_0/>. From 1857 to 1864, he studied inheritance patterns in 8000 common edible pea plants, tracking distinct traits from parent to offspring. He described these mathematically as 2n combinations where <a1_0>n is the number of differing characteristics in the original peas<a1_0/>. Although he did not use the term gene, he explained his results in terms of <a4_0>discrete inherited units that give rise to observable physical characteristics<a4_0/>. This description prefigured the distinction between genotype (the genetic material of an organism) and phenotype (the visible traits of that organism). Mendel was also the first to demonstrate <a2_0>independent assortment<a2_0/>, <a3_0>the distinction between dominant and recessive traits<a3_0/>, the distinction between a heterozygote and homozygote, and the phenomenon of discontinuous inheritance.
